  1. Condition system ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED (D028) ‚Äî Phase 2 exit criterion
  2. Multiplier system ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED (D028) ‚Äî Phase 2 exit criterion
  3. Full damage pipeline ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED (D028) ‚Äî Phase 2 exit criterion (Projectile ‚Üí Warhead ‚Üí Armor table ‚Üí Modifiers ‚Üí Health)
  4. Power system ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî Power component + PowerManager resource
  5. Building mechanics ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî BuildArea, PrimaryBuilding, RallyPoint, Exit, Sellable, Repairable, Gate, LineBuild
  6. Transport/Cargo ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî Cargo / Passenger components
  7. Capture ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî Capturable / Captures components
  8. Stealth/Cloak ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî Cloak / DetectCloaked components
  9. Infantry sub-cell ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî InfantryBody / SubCell enum
  10. Death mechanics ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî SpawnOnDeath, ExplodeOnDeath, SelfDestruct, DamageStates
  11. Transform/Deploy ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî Transforms component
  12. Veterancy (full system) ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî GainsExperience / GivesExperience + condition-based promotions
  13. Guard command ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî Guard / Guardable components
  14. Crush mechanics ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî Crushable / Crusher components

Phase 3 Additions (UI ‚Äî Months 12‚Äì16)

  1. Support Powers ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî SupportPower component + SupportPowerManager resource
  2. Cursor system ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî YAML-defined cursors, contextual resolution, force-modifiers
  3. Hotkey system ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî HotkeyConfig categories, rebindable, profiles
  4. Notification framework ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî NotificationType enum + NotificationCooldowns + EVA mapping
  5. Selection details ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî Priority, double-click, tab cycle, control groups, selection limit
  6. Game speed presets ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî 5 presets (SpeedPreset enum), lobby-configurable, runtime adjustable in SP
  7. Radar system (detailed) ‚Äî ‚ö†Ô∏è PARTIAL ‚Äî Minimap rendering is ic-ui responsibility; AppearsOnRadar implied but not a standalone component
  8. Power bar UI ‚Äî Part of ic-ui chrome design (Phase 3)
  9. Observer UI ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî Army/production/economy overlays, player switching, broadcast delay

Phase 4 Additions (Scripting ‚Äî Months 16‚Äì20)

  1. Lua API specification ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED (D024) ‚Äî strict superset of OpenRA‚Äôs 16 globals, identical signatures
  2. Crate system ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî Crate component + CrateAction variants
  3. Mine system ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî Mine / Minelayer components
  4. Demolition/C4 ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî Demolition component

Phase 6a/6b Additions (Modding & Ecosystem ‚Äî Months 26‚Äì32)

  1. Debug/developer tools ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî DeveloperMode flags, overlays, profiler, asset browser
  2. Encyclopedia ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî In-game encyclopedia with categories, stats, previews
  3. Localization framework ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî Fluent-based .ftl files, locale resource, CJK/RTL support
  4. Faction system (formal) ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî Faction YAML type with side grouping and tech trees
  5. Palette effects (runtime) ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî PaletteEffect enum (flash, fade, tint, cycle, remap)
  6. Asset browser ‚Äî ‚úÖ DESIGNED ‚Äî Part of IC SDK (D040)

Mod Migration Case Studies

Purpose: Validate Iron Curtain‚Äôs modding architecture against real-world OpenRA mods and official C&C products. These case studies answer: ‚ÄúCan the most ambitious community work actually run on our engine?‚Äù

Case Study 1: Combined Arms (OpenRA‚Äôs Most Ambitious Mod)

What Combined Arms Is

Combined Arms (CA) is the largest and most ambitious OpenRA mod in existence. It is effectively a standalone game:

  • 5 factions ‚Äî Allies, Soviets, GDI, Nod, Scrin
  • 20 sub-factions ‚Äî 4 unique variants per faction, each with distinct units, powers, and upgrades
  • 34 campaign missions ‚Äî Lua-scripted narrative across 8+ chapters, with co-op support
  • 450+ maps ‚Äî including competitive maps from base RA
  • Competitive ladder ‚Äî 1v1 ranked play with player statistics
  • 86 releases ‚Äî actively maintained, v1.08.1 released January 2026
  • 9.3/10 ModDB rating ‚Äî 45 reviews, 60K downloads, 482 watchers

CA represents the upper bound of what the OpenRA modding ecosystem has produced. If IC can support CA, it can support anything.

CA‚Äôs Technical Composition

LanguageSharePurpose
C#67.7%Custom engine traits (compiled DLLs)
Lua29.4%Campaign missions, scripted events
YAML (MiniYAML)~3%Unit definitions, weapon stats, rules

CA‚Äôs heavy C# usage is significant ‚Äî it means CA has outgrown OpenRA‚Äôs data-driven modding and needed to extend the engine itself. This is exactly the scenario IC‚Äôs three-tier modding architecture is designed to handle.

CA‚Äôs Custom Code Inventory

Surveyed from OpenRA.Mods.CA/ ‚Äî ~150+ custom C# files organized into:

Custom Traits (~90 files in Traits/)

CategoryCustom TraitsExamplesIC Equivalent
Mind Control5MindController, MindControllable, MindControllerCapacityModifierBuilt-in ECS component or WASM
Spawner/Carrier8CarrierMaster/Slave, AirstrikeMaster/Slave, SpawnerMasterBaseBuilt-in (needed for RA2/Scrin)
Teleport Network3TeleportNetwork, TeleportNetworkPrimaryExit, TeleportNetworkTransportableBuilt-in or WASM
Upgrades4Upgradeable, ProvidesUpgrade, RearmsToUpgradeYAML conditions system
Unit Abilities5TargetedAttackAbility, TargetedLeapAbility, TargetedDiveAbility, SpawnActorAbilityLua or WASM
Shields/Defense4Shielded, PointDefense, ReflectsDamage, ConvertsDamageToHealthBuilt-in or WASM
Missiles4BallisticMissile, CruiseMissile, GuidedMissile, MissileBaseBuilt-in projectile system
Transport/Cargo6CargoBlocked, CargoCloner, MassEntersCargo, PassengerBlockedBuilt-in + YAML
Deploy/Transform6DeployOnAttack, InstantTransforms, DetonateWeaponOnDeploy, AutoDeployerConditions + YAML
Resources6ChronoResourceDelivery, HarvesterBalancer, ConvertsResourcesYAML + Lua
Death/Spawn6SpawnActorOnDeath, SpawnRandomActorOnDeath, SpawnHuskEffectOnDeathBuilt-in + YAML
Experience5GivesBountyCA, GivesExperienceCA, GivesExperienceToMasterBuilt-in veterancy
Infiltration4+Subdirectory with multiple infiltration traitsBuilt-in + YAML
Berserk/Warp2Berserkable, WarpableWASM
Production4LinkedProducerSource/Target, PeriodicProducerCA, ProductionAirdropCABuilt-in + YAML
Attachable5Attachable, AttachableTo, AttachOnCreation, AttachOnTransformWASM
Stealth1Mirage (disguise as props)Built-in cloak system
Misc20+PopControlled, MadTankCA, KeepsDistance, LaysMinefield, Convertible, ChronoshiftableCAMixed

Also includes subdirectories: Air/, Attack/, BotModules/, Conditions/, Infiltration/, Modifiers/, Multipliers/, PaletteEffects/, Palettes/, Player/, Render/, Sound/, SupportPowers/, World/

Custom Warheads (24 files in Warheads/)

WarheadPurposeIC Equivalent
FireShrapnelWarheadSecondary projectiles on impactBuilt-in warhead pipeline
FireFragmentWarheadFragment weapons on detonationBuilt-in warhead pipeline
WarpDamageWarheadTemporal displacement damageWASM warhead module
SpawnActorWarheadSpawn units on detonationBuilt-in
SpawnBuildingWarheadCreate buildings on impactBuilt-in
AttachActorWarheadAttach parasites/bombsWASM
AttachDelayedWeaponWarheadTime-delayed weapon effectsBuilt-in timer system
InfiltrateWarheadSpy-type infiltration on hitBuilt-in infiltration
CreateTintedCellsWarheadTiberium-style terrain damageBuilt-in terrain system
SendAirstrikeWarheadTrigger airstrike on impactLua or WASM
HealthPercentageSpreadDamageWarhead%-based area damageBuilt-in damage pipeline
Others (13)Flash effects, condition grants, etc.Mixed

Custom Projectiles (16 files in Projectiles/)

ProjectileSizePurpose
LinearPulse65KBComplex line-based energy weapon
MissileCA40KBHeavily customized missile behavior
BulletCA17KBExtended bullet with tracking/effects
PlasmaBeam14KBScrin-style plasma weapon
RailgunCA11KBRailgun visual effect
ElectricBolt9KBTesla-style electrical discharge
AreaBeamCA10KBArea-effect beam weapon
ArcLaserZap5KBCurved laser visual
Others (8)VariesRadBeam, TeslaZapCA, KKNDLaser, etc.

Custom projectiles are primarily render code ‚Äî visual effects for weapon impacts. In IC, these map to shader effects and particle systems in ic-render, not simulation code.

Custom Activities (24 files in Activities/)

Activities are unit behaviors ‚Äî the ‚Äúverbs‚Äù that units perform:

  • Attach, Dive, DiveApproach, TargetedLeap ‚Äî special movement/attack patterns
  • BallisticMissileFly, CruiseMissileFly, GuidedMissileFly ‚Äî missile flight paths
  • EnterTeleportNetwork, TeleportCA ‚Äî teleportation mechanics
  • InstantTransform, Upgrade ‚Äî unit transformation
  • ChronoResourceTeleport ‚Äî chronoshift-style harvesting
  • MassRideTransport, ParadropCargo ‚Äî transport mechanics

In IC, activities map to ECS system behaviors, triggered by conditions or orders.

Migration Assessment

What Migrates Automatically (Zero Effort)

Asset TypeVolumeMethod
Sprite assets (.shp)HundredsIC loads natively (invariant #8)
Palette files (.pal)DozensIC loads natively
Sound effects (.aud)HundredsIC loads natively
Map files (.oramap)450+IC loads natively
MiniYAML rulesThousands of entriesLoads directly at runtime (D025) ‚Äî no conversion step
OpenRA YAML keysAll trait namesAccepted as aliases (D023) ‚Äî Armament and combat both work
OpenRA mod manifestmod.yamlParsed directly (D026) ‚Äî point IC at OpenRA mod dir
Lua mission scripts34 missionsRun unmodified (D024) ‚Äî IC Lua API is strict superset

What Migrates with Effort

ComponentEffortDetails
YAML unit definitionsZeroMiniYAML loads at runtime (D025), OpenRA trait names accepted as aliases (D023) ‚Äî no conversion needed
Lua campaign missionsZeroIC Lua API is a strict superset of OpenRA‚Äôs (D024) ‚Äî same 16 globals, same signatures, same return types; missions run unmodified
Custom traits ‚Üí Built-inNoneIC builds mind control, carriers, shields, teleport networks, upgrades, delayed weapons as Phase 2 first-party components (D029)
Custom traits ‚Üí YAML conditionsLowDeploy mechanics, upgrade toggles, transform states map to IC‚Äôs condition system (D028)
Custom traits ‚Üí WASMSignificant~20 truly novel traits need WASM rewrite: Berserkable, Warpable, KeepsDistance, Attachable system, custom ability targeting
Custom warheadsLowMany become built-in warhead pipeline extensions (D028); novel ones (WarpDamage, TintedCells) need WASM
Custom projectilesModerateThese are primarily render code; rewrite as ic-render shader effects and particle systems
Custom UI widgetsModerateCA has custom widgets; these need Bevy UI reimplementation
Bot modulesLow-ModerateMap to ic-ai crate‚Äôs bot system

Migration Tier Breakdown

‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
‚îÇ     Combined Arms ‚Üí Iron Curtain Migration      ‚îÇ
‚îÇ           (after D023‚ÄìD029)                      ‚îÇ
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î§
‚îÇ                                                 ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  Tier 1 (YAML)  ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà ~45%    ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  No code change needed. Unit stats, weapons,    ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  armor tables, build trees, faction setup.       ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  MiniYAML loads directly (D025).                 ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  OpenRA trait names accepted as aliases (D023).  ‚îÇ
‚îÇ                                                 ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  Built-in       ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà  ~40%    ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  IC includes as first-party ECS components       ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  (D029). Mind control, carriers, shields,        ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  teleport, upgrades, delayed weapons,            ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  veterancy, infiltration, damage pipeline.       ‚îÇ
‚îÇ                                                 ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  Tier 2 (Lua)   ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà              ~10%      ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  Campaign missions run unmodified (D024).        ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  IC Lua API is strict superset of OpenRA's.      ‚îÇ
‚îÇ                                                 ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  Tier 3 (WASM)  ‚ñà‚ñà‚ñà                ~5%       ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  Truly novel mechanics only: Berserkable,        ‚îÇ
‚îÇ  Warpable, KeepsDistance, Attachable.             ‚îÇ
‚îÇ                                                 ‚îÇ
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò

What CA Gains by Migrating

BenefitDetails
No more engine version treadmillCA currently pins to OpenRA releases, rebasing C# against every engine update. IC‚Äôs mod API is versioned and stable.
Better performanceCA with 5 factions pushes OpenRA hard. IC‚Äôs efficiency pyramid (multi-layer hybrid pathfinding, spatial hashing, sim LOD) handles large battles better.
Better multiplayerRelay server, sub-tick ordering, signed replays, ranked infrastructure built in ‚Äî no custom ladder server needed.
Hot-reloadable modsChange YAML, see results immediately. No recompilation ever.
Workshop distributionic CLI tool packages and publishes mods. No manual download/install.
Branching campaigns (D021)IC‚Äôs narrative graph with persistent unit roster would elevate CA‚Äôs 34 missions significantly.
WASM sandboxingCustom code runs in a sandbox with capability-based API ‚Äî no risk of mods crashing the engine or accessing filesystem.
Cross-platform for freeCA currently packages per-platform. IC runs on Windows/Mac/Linux/Browser/Mobile from one codebase.

Verdict

Not plug-and-play, but a realistic and beneficial migration ‚Äî dramatically improved by D023‚ÄìD029.

  • ~95% of content (YAML rules via D025 runtime loading + D023 aliases, assets, maps, Lua missions via D024 superset API, built-in mechanics via D029) migrates with zero effort ‚Äî no conversion tools, no code changes.
  • ~5% of content (~20 truly novel C# traits) requires WASM rewrites ‚Äî bounded and well-identified.
  • The migration is a net positive: CA ends up with better performance, multiplayer, distribution, and maintainability.
  • Zero-friction evaluation: Point IC at an OpenRA mod directory (D026) and it loads. No commitment required to test.
  • IC benefits too: CA‚Äôs requirements for mind control, teleport networks, carriers, shields, and upgrades validate and drive our component library design. If IC supports CA, it supports any OpenRA mod.

Lessons for IC Design

CA‚Äôs codebase reveals which OpenRA gaps force modders into C#. These should become first-party IC features:

  1. Mind Control ‚Äî Full system: controller, controllable, capacity limits, progress bars, spawn-on-mind-controlled. Needed for Yuri/Scrin in future game modules.
  2. Carrier/Spawner ‚Äî Master/slave with drone AI, return-to-carrier, respawn timers. Needed for Kirov, Aircraft Carriers, Scrin Mothership.
  3. Teleport Networks ‚Äî Enter any, exit at primary. Needed for Nod tunnels in TD/TS.
  4. Shield Systems ‚Äî Absorb damage, recharge, deplete. Needed for Scrin and RA2 force shields.
  5. Upgrade System ‚Äî Per-unit tech upgrades purchased at buildings. Needed for C&C3-style gameplay.
  6. Delayed Weapons ‚Äî Attach timers to targets. Common RTS mechanic (poison, radiation, time bombs).
  7. Attachable Actors ‚Äî Parasite/bomb attachment. Terror drones in RA2.

These seven systems cover ~60% of CA‚Äôs custom C# code and are universally useful across C&C game modules.

Case Study 2: C&C Remastered Collection

What Remastered Delivers

The C&C Remastered Collection (Petroglyph/EA, 2020) modernized C&C95 and Red Alert with:

  • HD/SD toggle ‚Äî Press F1 to instantly swap between classic 320√ó200 sprites and remastered HD art (4096-color, hand-painted)
  • 4K support ‚Äî HD assets render at native resolution up to 3840√ó2160
  • Zoom ‚Äî Camera zoom in/out (not in original)
  • Modern UI ‚Äî Cleaner sidebar, rally points, attack-move, queued production
  • Remastered audio ‚Äî Frank Klepacki re-recorded the entire soundtrack; jukebox mode
  • Classic gameplay ‚Äî Deliberately preserved original balance and feel
  • Bonus gallery ‚Äî Concept art, behind-the-scenes, FMV jukebox

This is the gold standard for C&C modernization. The question: could someone achieve this on IC?

How IC‚Äôs Architecture Supports Each Feature

HD/SD Graphics Toggle

IC handles this through D048 (Switchable Render Modes) ‚Äî a first-class engine concept that bundles render backend, camera, resource packs, and visual config into a named, instantly-switchable unit. The Remastered Collection‚Äôs F1 toggle is exactly the use case D048 was designed for, and IC generalizes it further: not just classic‚ÜîHD, but classic‚ÜîHD‚Üî3D if a 3D render mod is installed.

Three converging architectural decisions make it work:

Invariant #9 (game-agnostic renderer): The engine uses a Renderable trait. The RA1 game module registers sprite rendering, but the engine doesn‚Äôt know what format the sprites are. A game module can register multiple render modes and swap at runtime.

Invariant #10 (platform-agnostic): ‚ÄúRender quality is runtime-configurable.‚Äù This is literally the HD/SD toggle stated as an architectural requirement.

Bevy‚Äôs asset system: Both classic .shp sprites and HD texture atlases load as Bevy asset handles. The toggle swaps which handle the Renderable component references. This is a frame-instant operation ‚Äî no loading screen required. Cross-backend switches (2D‚Üî3D) load on first toggle, instant thereafter.

Implementation sketch:

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
/// Component that tracks which asset quality to render
#[derive(Component)]
struct RenderQuality {
    classic: Handle<SpriteSheet>,
    hd: Option<Handle<SpriteSheet>>,
    active: Quality, // Classic | HD
}

/// System: swap sprite sheet on toggle
fn toggle_render_quality(
    input: Res<Input>,
    mut query: Query<&mut RenderQuality>,
) {
    if input.just_pressed(KeyCode::F1) {
        for mut rq in &mut query {
            rq.active = match rq.active {
                Quality::Classic => Quality::HD,
                Quality::HD => Quality::Classic,
            };
        }
    }
}
}

YAML-level support:

# Unit definition with dual asset sets
e1:
  render:
    sprite:
      classic: infantry/e1.shp
      hd: infantry/e1_hd.png
    palette:
      classic: temperat.pal
      hd: null  # HD uses embedded color
    shadow:
      classic: infantry/e1_shadow.shp
      hd: infantry/e1_shadow_hd.png

4K Native Rendering

Bevy + wgpu handle arbitrary resolutions natively. The isometric renderer in ic-render would:

  • Detect native display resolution via Bevy‚Äôs window system
  • Classify into ScreenClass (our responsive UI system from invariant #10)
  • Classic sprites: integer-scaled (2√ó, 3√ó, 4√ó, 6√ó) with nearest-neighbor filtering to preserve pixel art
  • HD sprites: render at native resolution, no scaling artifacts
  • UI elements: adapt layout per ScreenClass (phone ‚Üí tablet ‚Üí laptop ‚Üí desktop ‚Üí 4K)
DisplayClassic ModeHD Mode
1080p3√ó integer scaleNative HD
1440p4√ó integer scaleNative HD
4K6√ó integer scaleNative HD
UltrawideScale + letterbox optionsNative HD, wider viewport

Camera Zoom

Standard Bevy camera parameter. The isometric renderer already needs to handle different view distances for the minimap and observer mode. Zoom is a single f32 on the camera entity ‚Äî trivial to expose as scroll-wheel or keybind.

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
fn camera_zoom(
    input: Res<Input>,
    mut camera: Query<&mut OrthographicProjection, With<GameCamera>>,
) {
    let scroll = input.mouse_scroll_delta();
    for mut proj in &mut camera {
        proj.scale = (proj.scale - scroll.y * 0.1).clamp(0.5, 3.0);
    }
}
}

Modern UI / Sidebar

  • IC‚Äôs ic-ui crate uses Bevy UI ‚Äî not locked to OpenRA‚Äôs widget system
  • The Remastered sidebar layout is our explicit UX reference (AGENTS.md: ‚ÄúEA Remastered Collection ‚Äî UI/UX gold standard. Cleanest, least cluttered C&C interface.‚Äù)
  • Rally points, attack-move, queued production are standard Phase 3 deliverables
  • A remastered UI theme could coexist with a classic theme ‚Äî switchable in settings

Remastered Audio

IC‚Äôs ic-audio crate supports:

  • Classic .aud format (loaded natively per invariant #8)
  • Modern audio formats (WAV, OGG, FLAC) via Bevy‚Äôs audio plugin
  • Jukebox mode is a UI feature ‚Äî trivial playlist management
  • EVA voice system supports multiple voice packs
  • Spatial audio for positional effects (explosions, gunfire)

A ‚ÄúRemastered audio pack‚Äù would be a mod containing high-quality re-recordings alongside classic .aud files, with a toggle in audio settings.

Balance Preservation

D019 (Switchable Balance Presets) explicitly defines remastered as a preset:

# rules/presets/remastered.yaml
# Any balance changes from the EA Remastered Collection.
# Selected in lobby alongside "classic" and "openra" presets.
preset: remastered
source: "C&C Remastered Collection (2020)"
inherit: classic
overrides:
  # Document specific deviations from original balance here

Players choose in lobby: Classic (EA source values), OpenRA (OpenRA balance), or Remastered.

What It Would Take

ComponentEffortNotes
Classic assetsZeroIC loads .shp, .pal, .aud, .tmp natively (invariant #8)
HD art assetsMajor art effortEA‚Äôs HD sprites are copyrighted; must be created independently
HD/SD toggle systemModerateDual asset handles per entity, runtime swap, ~2 weeks engineering
4K renderingFreeBevy/wgpu handles natively
Integer scalingLowNearest-neighbor upscale for classic sprites, configurable scale factor
Camera zoomTrivialSingle camera parameter, hours of work
Remastered UI themeModerateBevy UI layout, reference EA Remastered screenshots
Remastered balance presetLowYAML data file comparing EA Remastered balance to original
Remastered audio packArt effortCommunity re-recordings or licensed audio
Bonus galleryLowImage viewer + FMV player (IC already plans .vqa support)

The Art Bottleneck

The engineering is straightforward. The bottleneck is art assets:

EA‚Äôs HD sprites for the Remastered Collection are copyrighted and cannot be redistributed. A community-driven Remastered experience on IC would need:

  1. Commission original HD art in the Remastered style ‚Äî expensive but legally clear
  2. AI upscaling of classic sprites ‚Äî lower quality, fast, legally ambiguous
  3. Community art packs distributed via workshop ‚Äî distributed effort, curated quality
  4. Open-source HD asset projects ‚Äî several community efforts exist for C&C sprite HD conversions

IC‚Äôs architecture makes the engine part trivial. The GameModule trait (D018) means a remastered module can register HD asset loaders, the dual-render toggle, UI theme, and balance preset. The engine doesn‚Äôt care ‚Äî it‚Äôs game-agnostic.

Implementation as a Game Module

The full Remastered experience would be a game module (D018):

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
pub struct RemasteredModule;

impl GameModule for RemasteredModule {
    fn name(&self) -> &str { "C&C Remastered" }

    fn register_systems(&self, app: &mut App) {
        // Everything from RA1Module, plus:
        app.add_systems(Update, toggle_render_quality);
        app.add_systems(Update, camera_zoom);

        // Register HD asset loaders alongside classic ones
        app.add_plugins(HdSpritePlugin);
        app.add_plugins(HdAudioPlugin);

        // Remastered UI theme
        app.insert_resource(UiTheme::Remastered);

        // Balance preset
        app.insert_resource(BalancePreset::Remastered);
    }

    fn register_assets(&self, server: &AssetServer) {
        // Load both classic and HD asset sets
        server.register_loader::<ShpLoader>();   // Classic
        server.register_loader::<HdPngLoader>(); // HD
    }
}
}

Verdict

Yes, someone could recreate the Remastered experience on IC. The architecture explicitly supports it:

  • Game-agnostic engine with GameModule trait (D018) ‚Äî Remastered becomes a module
  • Switchable render modes (D048) ‚Äî F1 toggles Classic‚ÜîHD‚Üî3D, same as Remastered‚Äôs F1
  • Switchable balance presets (D019) ‚Äî remastered preset alongside classic and openra
  • Full original format compatibility (invariant #8) ‚Äî classic assets load unchanged
  • Bevy/wgpu for modern rendering ‚Äî 4K, zoom, post-processing, all native
  • Cross-view multiplayer ‚Äî one player on Classic, another on HD, same game

The bottleneck is art, not engineering. If someone produced HD sprite assets compatible with IC‚Äôs asset system, the engine work for the HD/SD toggle, 4K rendering, zoom, and modern UI is straightforward Bevy development ‚Äî estimated at 4-6 weeks of focused engineering on top of the base RA1 game module.

This case study validates IC‚Äôs multi-game architecture: the same engine that runs classic RA1 can deliver a Remastered-quality experience as a different game module, with zero changes to the engine core.

Cross-Cutting Insights

Both case studies validate the same architectural decisions:

DecisionCA ValidationRemastered Validation
D018 (Game Modules)CA‚Äôs 5 factions = a game module that registers more components than base RA1Remastered = a module that registers dual asset loaders
Tiered Modding40% YAML + 15% Lua + 15% WASM + 30% built-in95% data/asset-driven, 5% module code
Invariant #8 (Format Compat)450+ maps, all sprites, all audio load nativelyAll classic assets load natively
Invariant #9 (Game-Agnostic)Scrin/GDI/Nod require engine-agnostic component designHD renderer is game-agnostic
Invariant #10 (Platform-Agnostic)Must run on all platforms with same mod contentRuntime render quality = HD/SD toggle
D019 (Balance Presets)CA‚Äôs custom balance is just another presetremastered preset
D021 (Campaigns)CA‚Äôs 34 missions benefit from branching narrative graphRemastered‚Äôs campaigns could use persistent roster

Seven Built-In Systems Driven by These Case Studies

Based on CA‚Äôs custom C# requirements and Remastered‚Äôs features, IC should include these as first-party engine components (not mod-level WASM):

  1. Mind Control ‚Äî Controller/controllable with capacity limits, progress indication, spawn-on-override
  2. Carrier/Spawner ‚Äî Master/slave drone management with respawn, recall, autonomous attack
  3. Teleport Network ‚Äî Multi-node network with primary exit designation
  4. Shield System ‚Äî Absorb damage before health, recharge timer, visual effects
  5. Upgrade System ‚Äî Per-unit tech upgrades via building research, with conditions
  6. Delayed Weapons ‚Äî Time-delayed effects attached to targets (poison, radiation, bombs)
  7. Dual Asset Rendering ‚Äî Runtime-switchable asset quality (classic/HD) per entity

These seven systems serve both case studies, all future C&C game modules (RA2, TS, C&C3), and the broader RTS modding community.

Case Study 3: OpenKrush (KKnD) ‚Äî Total Conversion Acid Test

What OpenKrush Is

OpenKrush (116‚òÖ) is a recreation of KKnD (Krush Kill ‚Äòn‚Äô Destroy) on the OpenRA engine. It is the most extreme test of game-agnostic claims because KKnD shares almost nothing with C&C at the mechanics level. For full technical analysis, see research/openra-mod-architecture-analysis.md.

What Makes OpenKrush Architecturally Significant

OpenKrush replaces 16 complete mechanic modules from OpenRA‚Äôs C&C-oriented defaults:

ModuleWhat OpenKrush ReplacesIC Design Implication
Construction systemSelfConstructing + TechBunker (not C&C-style MCV)GameModule::system_pipeline() must accept arbitrary construction systems
Production systemPer-building production with local rally points, no sidebarProductionQueue is a game-module component, not an engine type
Resource modelOil patches (fixed positions, no regrowth, per-patch depletion)ResourceCell assumptions (growth_rate, max_amount) don‚Äôt apply
VeterancyKills-based (not XP points), custom promotion thresholdsVeterancy system must be trait-abstracted or YAML-configurable
Fog of warModified fog behaviorFogProvider trait validates
AI systemCustom AI modules (7 replacement bot modules)AiStrategy trait validates
UI chromeCustom sidebar, production panels, minimapic-ui layout profiles must be fully swappable per game module
Format loaders15+ custom binary decoders (.blit, .mobd, .mapd, .lvl, .son, .vbc)FormatRegistry + WASM format loaders are not optional for non-C&C
Map format.lvl terrain format (not .oramap)Map loading must go through game module, not hardcoded
Audio format.son/.soun (not .aud)Audio pipeline must accept game-module format loaders
Sprite format.blit/.mobd (not .shp)Sprite pipeline must accept game-module format loaders
Research systemTech research per building (not prerequisite tree)Prerequisite model is game-module-defined
Bunker systemCapturable tech bunkers with unique unlocksCapture/garrison mechanics vary per game
Docking systemOil derrick docking (not refinery docking)Dock types are game-module-defined
Saboteur systemSaboteur infiltration/destructionSpy/saboteur mechanics vary per game
Power systemNo power (KKnD has no power grid)Power system must be optional, not assumed

What This Validates in IC‚Äôs Architecture

OpenKrush is the strongest evidence that invariant #9 (engine core is game-agnostic) is not aspirational ‚Äî it‚Äôs required. Every GameModule trait method that IC defines maps to a real replacement that OpenKrush needed:

  • register_format_loaders() ‚Üí 15+ custom format decoders
  • system_pipeline() ‚Üí 16 replaced mechanic systems
  • pathfinder() ‚Üí modified pathfinding for different terrain model
  • render_modes() ‚Üí different sprite pipeline for .blit/.mobd formats
  • rule_schema() ‚Üí different unit/building/research YAML structure

IC design lesson: If a KKnD total conversion doesn‚Äôt work on IC without engine modifications, the GameModule abstraction has failed. OpenKrush is the acid test.

Case Study 4: OpenSA (Swarm Assault) ‚Äî Non-C&C Genre Test

What OpenSA Is

OpenSA (114‚òÖ) is a recreation of Swarm Assault on the OpenRA engine. It represents an even more extreme departure from C&C than OpenKrush ‚Äî it‚Äôs not just a different RTS, it‚Äôs a fundamentally different game structure built on RTS infrastructure.

What Makes OpenSA Architecturally Significant

OpenSA tests whether the engine can handle the absence of core C&C systems, not just their replacement:

C&C SystemOpenSA EquivalentIC Design Implication
Construction yardNone ‚Äî no base buildingEngine must not assume a construction system exists
Sidebar/build queueNone ‚Äî production via colony captureEngine must not assume a sidebar UI exists
Harvesting/resourcesNone ‚Äî no resource gatheringEngine must not assume a resource model exists
Tech treeNone ‚Äî no prerequisitesEngine must not assume a tech tree exists
Power gridNone ‚Äî no powerAlready optional (see OpenKrush)
Infantry/vehicle splitInsects with custom locomotorsUnit categories are game-module-defined
Static defensesColony buildings (capturable, not buildable)Defense structures vary per game

Custom Systems OpenSA Adds

SystemDescriptionIC Design Implication
Plant growthLiving terrain: plants spread, creating cover and resourcesWorldLayer abstraction for cell-level autonomous behavior
Creep spawnersMap hazards that periodically spawn hostile creaturesWorld-level entity spawning system (not just player production)
Pirate antsNeutral hostile faction with autonomous behaviorAI-controlled neutral factions as a first-class concept
Colony captureTake over colony buildings to gain production capabilityCapture-to-produce is a different model than build-to-produce
WaspLocomotorFlying insect movement (not aircraft, not helicopter)Custom locomotors via game module (validates Pathfinder trait)
Per-building productionEach colony produces its own unit typeFurther validates production-as-game-module pattern

What This Validates in IC‚Äôs Architecture

OpenSA demonstrates that a viable game module might use none of IC‚Äôs RA1 systems ‚Äî no sidebar, no construction, no harvesting, no tech tree, no power. The engine must function as pure infrastructure (ECS, rendering, networking, input, audio) with all gameplay systems provided by the game module.

IC design lesson: The GameModule trait must be sufficient for games that share almost nothing with C&C except the underlying engine. If OpenSA-style games require engine modifications, the abstraction is too thin. The engine core provides: tick management, order dispatch, fog of war interface, pathfinding interface, rendering pipeline, networking, and modding infrastructure. Everything else ‚Äî including ‚Äúcore RTS features‚Äù like base building and resource gathering ‚Äî is a game module concern.

Development Philosophy

How Iron Curtain makes decisions ‚Äî grounded in the publicly-stated principles of the people who created Command & Conquer (Westwood Studios / EA) and the community that carried their work forward (OpenRA).

Purpose of This Chapter

This chapter exists so that every design decision, code review, and feature proposal on Iron Curtain can be evaluated against a consistent set of principles ‚Äî principles that aren‚Äôt invented by us, but inherited from the people who built this genre.

When to read this chapter:

  • You‚Äôre evaluating a feature proposal and need to decide whether it belongs
  • You‚Äôre reviewing code or design and want criteria beyond ‚Äúdoes it compile?‚Äù
  • You‚Äôre choosing between two valid approaches and need a tiebreaker
  • You‚Äôre adding a new system and want to check it against IC‚Äôs design culture
  • You‚Äôre making a temporary compromise and need to know how to keep it reversible

When NOT to read this chapter:

  • You need architecture specifics ‚Üí 02-ARCHITECTURE.md
  • You need to check if something was already decided ‚Üí 09-DECISIONS.md
  • You need performance guidance ‚Üí 10-PERFORMANCE.md
  • You need the phase timeline ‚Üí 08-ROADMAP.md

Full evidence and quotes are in research/westwood-ea-development-philosophy.md. This chapter distills the actionable guidelines. The research file has the receipts.

The Core Question

Every feature, system, and design decision should pass one test before anything else:

‚ÄúDoes this make the toy soldiers come alive?‚Äù

‚Äî Joe Bostic, creator of Dune II and Command & Conquer

Bostic described the RTS genre as recreating the imaginary combat he had as a child playing with toy soldiers in a sandbox. Louis Castle added the ‚Äúbedroom commander‚Äù fantasy ‚Äî the interface isn‚Äôt a game UI, it‚Äôs a live military feed you‚Äôre hacking into from your bedroom. This isn‚Äôt metaphor ‚Äî it‚Äôs the literal design origin. Advanced features (LLM missions, WASM mods, relay servers, competitive infrastructure) exist to serve this fantasy. If a feature doesn‚Äôt serve it, it needs strong justification.

Design Principles

These are drawn from publicly-stated positions by Westwood‚Äôs creators and the OpenRA team‚Äôs documented decisions. Each principle maps to specific IC decisions and design docs. They are guidelines, not a rigid checklist ‚Äî the original creators discovered their best ideas by iterating, not by following specifications.

1. Fun Beats Documentation

‚ÄúWe were free to come up with crazy new ideas for units and added them in if they felt like fun.‚Äù

‚Äî Joe Bostic on Red Alert‚Äôs origins

Red Alert started as an expansion pack. Ideas that felt fun kept getting added until it outgrew its scope. The filter was never ‚Äúdoes this fit the spec?‚Äù ‚Äî it was ‚Äúis this fun?‚Äù

Canonical Example: The Unit Cap. Competitors like Warcraft used unit caps for balance and performance. Westwood rejected them. Castle: ‚ÄúYou like the idea that people could build tons of units and go marching across the world and just mow everything down. That was lots of fun.‚Äù Fun beat the technical specification.

Rule: If something plays well but contradicts a design doc, update the doc. If something is in the doc but plays poorly, cut it. The docs serve the game, not the other way around.

Where this applies:

  • Gameplay systems in 02-ARCHITECTURE.md ‚Äî system designs can evolve during implementation
  • Balance presets in D019 (09-DECISIONS.md) ‚Äî multiple balance approaches coexist precisely because ‚Äúfun‚Äù is subjective
  • QoL toggles in D033 ‚Äî experimental features can be toggled, not permanently committed

2. Fix Invariants Early, Iterate Everything Else

‚ÄúWe knew from the start that the game had to play in real-time‚Ä¶ but the idea of harvesting to gain credits to purchase more units was thought of in the middle of development.‚Äù

‚Äî Joe Bostic on Dune II

Westwood fixed the non-negotiables (real-time play) and discovered everything else through building. The RTS genre was iterated into existence, not designed on paper.

Rule: IC‚Äôs 10 architectural invariants (AGENTS.md) are locked. Everything else ‚Äî specific game systems, UI patterns, balance values ‚Äî evolves through implementation. The phased roadmap (08-ROADMAP.md) leaves room for iteration within each phase while protecting the invariants.

3. Separate Simulation from I/O

‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt have to do much alteration of the original code except to replace the rendering and networking layers.‚Äù

‚Äî Joe Bostic on the C&C Remastered codebase, 25 years after the original

This is the single most validated engineering principle in C&C‚Äôs history. Westwood‚Äôs 1995 sim layer survived a complete platform change in 2020 because it was pure ‚Äî no rendering, no networking, no I/O in the game logic. The Remastered Collection runs the original C++ sim as a headless DLL called from C#.

Rule: The sim is the part that survives decades. Keep it pure. ic-sim has zero imports from ic-net or ic-render. This is Invariant #1 and #2 ‚Äî violations are bugs, not trade-offs.

Where this applies:

  • Crate boundary enforcement in 02-ARCHITECTURE.md ¬ß crate structure
  • NetworkModel trait in 03-NETCODE.md ‚Äî sim never knows about the network
  • Snapshot/restore architecture in 02-ARCHITECTURE.md ‚Äî pure sim enables saves, replays, rollback, desync debugging

4. Data-Driven Everything

The original C&C stored all game values in INI files. Designers iterated without recompiling. The community discovered this and modding was born. OpenRA inherited this as MiniYAML. The Remastered Collection preserved it.

Rule: Game values belong in YAML, not Rust code. If a modder would want to change it, it shouldn‚Äôt require recompilation. This is the foundation of the tiered modding system (D003/D004/D005).

Validated by Factorio: Wube Software takes this principle to its logical extreme ‚Äî Factorio‚Äôs base/ directory defines the entire base game using the same data:extend() Lua API available to modders. The game itself is a mod. This ‚Äúgame is a mod‚Äù architecture (see research/mojang-wube-modding-analysis.md) is the strongest possible guarantee that the modding API is complete and stable: if the base game can‚Äôt do something without internal APIs, the modding API is incomplete. IC‚Äôs RA1 game module should aspire to the same standard ‚Äî every system registered through GameModule trait (D018), no internal shortcuts unavailable to external modules.

Where this applies:

  • YAML rule system in 04-MODDING.md ‚Äî 80% of mods achievable with YAML alone
  • OpenRA vocabulary compatibility (D023) ‚Äî Armament in OpenRA YAML routes to IC‚Äôs combat component
  • Runtime MiniYAML loading (D025) ‚Äî OpenRA mods load without manual conversion

5. Encourage Experimentation

‚ÄúThe most important thing I can stress about that process was that I was encouraged to experiment and tap into a wide variety of influences.‚Äù

‚Äî Frank Klepacki on composing the C&C soundtrack

Klepacki wasn‚Äôt given a brief that said ‚Äúwrite military rock.‚Äù He had freedom to explore ‚Äî thrash metal, electronic, ambient, everything. The result was one of the most distinctive game soundtracks ever made. Style emerged from experimentation, not from a spec.

‚ÄúI believe first and foremost I should write good music first that I‚Äôm happy with and figure out how to adapt it later.‚Äù

‚Äî Frank Klepacki

Rule: Build the best version first, then adapt for constraints. Don‚Äôt pre-optimize into mediocrity. This aligns with the performance pyramid in 10-PERFORMANCE.md: get the algorithm right first, then worry about cache layout and allocation patterns.

6. Scope to What You Have

‚ÄúInstead of having one excellent game mode, we ended up with two less-than-excellent game modes.‚Äù

‚Äî Mike Legg on Pirates: The Legend of Black Kat

Legg‚Äôs candid assessment: splitting effort across too many features produces mediocrity in all of them. Westwood learned this the hard way.

‚ÄúThe magic to creating those games was probably due to small teams with great passion.‚Äù

‚Äî Joe Bostic

Rule: Each roadmap phase delivers specific systems well, not everything at once. Phase 2 delivers simulation. Not simulation-plus-rendering-plus-networking-plus-modding. The phase exit criteria in 08-ROADMAP.md define ‚Äúdone‚Äù so that scope doesn‚Äôt silently expand. Don‚Äôt plan for 50 contributors when you have 5.

7. Make Temporary Compromises Explicit

‚ÄúMany of these changes were introduced in the early days of OpenRA to help balance the game and make it play well despite missing core gameplay features‚Ä¶ Over time, these changes became entrenched, for better or worse, as part of OpenRA‚Äôs identity.‚Äù

‚Äî Paul Chote, OpenRA lead maintainer, on design debt

OpenRA made early gameplay compromises (kill bounties, Allied Hinds, auto-targeting) to ship a playable game before core features existed. Those compromises hardened into permanent identity. When the team wanted to reconsider years later, the community was split.

Rule: Label experiments as experiments. Use D033‚Äôs toggle system so that every QoL or gameplay variant can be individually enabled/disabled. Early-phase compromises must never become irrevocable identity. If a system is a placeholder, document it as one ‚Äî in code comments, in the relevant design doc, and in 09-DECISIONS.md.

8. Great Teams Make Great Games

‚ÄúYour team and the people you choose to be around are more important to your success than any awesome technical skills you can acquire. Develop those technical skills but stay humble.‚Äù

‚Äî Denzil Long, Westwood engineer

‚ÄúThe success of Westwood was due to the passion, vision, creativity and leadership of Louis Castle and Brett Sperry ‚Äî all backed up by an incredible team of game makers.‚Äù

‚Äî Mike Legg

Every Westwood developer interviewed ‚Äî independently ‚Äî described the same thing: quality came from team culture, not from process. Playtest sessions led to hallway conversations that led to the best ideas. Process followed from culture, not the reverse.

Rule: IC‚Äôs ‚Äúteam‚Äù is its contributors and community. The public design docs, clear invariants, and documented decisions serve the same purpose as Westwood‚Äôs hallway conversations ‚Äî they make it possible for people to contribute effectively without requiring everyone to hold the same context. When invariants feel like overhead rather than values, something has gone wrong.

9. Avoid ‚ÄúArtificial Idiocy‚Äù

‚ÄúYou just want to avoid artificial idiocy. If you spend more time just making sure it doesn‚Äôt do something stupid, it‚Äôll actually look pretty smart.‚Äù

‚Äî Louis Castle, 2019

The goal of pathfinding and AI isn‚Äôt mathematical perfection. It‚Äôs believability. A unit that takes a slightly suboptimal route is fine. A unit that vibrates back and forth because it recalculated its path every tick and couldn‚Äôt decide is ‚Äúartificial idiocy.‚Äù

Rule: When designing AI or pathfinding, do not aim for ‚Äúoptimal.‚Äù Aim for ‚Äúpredictable.‚Äù Rely on heuristics (see ‚ÄúLayered Pathfinding Heuristics‚Äù in Engineering Methods below) rather than expensive perfection.

10. Build With the Community, Not Just For Them

Iron Curtain exists because of a community ‚Äî the players and modders who kept C&C alive for 30 years through OpenRA, competitive leagues (RAGL), third-party mods (Combined Arms, Romanov‚Äôs Vengeance), and preservation projects. Every design decision should consider how it affects these people.

This means:

  • Check community pain points before designing. OpenRA‚Äôs issue tracker (135+ desync issues, recurring modding friction, performance complaints), forum discussions, and mod developer feedback are primary design inputs, not afterthoughts. If a recurring complaint exists, the design should address it ‚Äî or explicitly document why it doesn‚Äôt.
  • Don‚Äôt break what works. The community has invested years in maps, mods, and workflows. Compatibility decisions (D023, D025, D026, D027) aren‚Äôt just technical ‚Äî they‚Äôre respect for people‚Äôs work.
  • Governance follows community, not the other way around. D037 is aspirational until a real community exists. Don‚Äôt build election systems for a project with five contributors.
  • Earn trust through transparency. Public design docs, documented decision rationale, and honest scope communication (no ‚ÄúRA2 coming soon‚Äù when nobody is building it) are how an open-source project earns contributors.

Rule: Before finalizing any design decision, ask: ‚ÄúHow does this affect the people who will actually use this?‚Äù Check the community pain points documented in 01-VISION.md, the OpenRA gap analysis in 11-OPENRA-FEATURES.md, and the governance principles in D037. If a decision benefits the architecture but hurts the community experience, the community experience wins ‚Äî unless an architectural invariant is at stake.

Game Design Principles

The principles above guide how we build. The principles below guide what we build ‚Äî the player-facing design philosophy that Westwood refined across a decade of RTS games. These are drawn from GDC talks (Louis Castle, 1997 & 1998), Ars Technica‚Äôs ‚ÄúWar Stories‚Äù interview (Castle, 2019), and post-mortem interviews. They complement the development principles ‚Äî if ‚ÄúFun Beats Documentation‚Äù says how to decide, these say what to aim for.

11. Immediate Feedback ‚Äî The One-Second Rule

Louis Castle emphasized that players should receive feedback for every action within one second. Click a unit ‚Äî it acknowledges with a voice line and visual cue. Issue an order ‚Äî the unit visibly begins responding. The player should never wonder ‚Äúdid the game hear me?‚Äù

This isn‚Äôt about latency targets ‚Äî it‚Äôs about perceived responsiveness. A click that produces silence is worse than a click that produces a ‚Äúnot yet‚Äù response.

Rule: Every player action must produce audible and visible feedback within one second. Unit selection ‚Üí voice line. Order issued ‚Üí animation change. Build started ‚Üí sound cue. If a system doesn‚Äôt have feedback, it needs feedback before it needs features.

Where this applies:

  • Unit voice and animation responses in ic-render and ic-audio (Phase 3)
  • Build queue feedback in ic-ui (Phase 3)
  • Input handling in ic-game ‚Äî cursor changes, click acknowledgment

12. Visual Clarity ‚Äî The One-Second Screenshot

You should be able to look at a screenshot for one second and know: who is winning, what units are on screen, and where the resources are. This was a core Westwood design test. If the screen is confusing, it doesn‚Äôt matter how deep the strategy is ‚Äî the player has lost contact with their toy soldiers.

Rule: Unit silhouettes must be distinguishable at gameplay zoom. Faction colors must read clearly. Resource locations must be visually distinct from terrain. Health states should be glanceable. When designing sprites, effects, or UI, ask: ‚ÄúCan I read this in one second?‚Äù

Where this applies:

  • Sprite design guidelines for modders in 04-MODDING.md
  • Render quality tiers in 10-PERFORMANCE.md ‚Äî even the lowest tier must preserve readability
  • Color palette choices for faction differentiation

13. Reduce Cognitive Load ‚Äî Smart Defaults

Westwood‚Äôs context-sensitive cursor was one of their greatest contributions to the genre: the cursor changes based on what it‚Äôs over (attack icon on enemies, move icon on terrain, harvest icon on resources), so the player communicates intent with a single click. The sidebar build menu was a deliberate choice to let players manage their base without moving the camera away from combat.

The principle: never make the player think about how to do something when they should be thinking about what to do.

Rule: Interface design should minimize the gap between player intent and game action. Default to the most likely action. Cursor, hotkeys, and UI layout should match what the player is already thinking. This extends to modding: mod installation should be one click, not a manual file dance.

Where this applies:

  • Input system design via InputSource trait (Invariant #10)
  • UI layout in ic-ui ‚Äî sidebar vs bottom-bar is a theme choice (D032), but all layouts should follow ‚Äúbuild without losing the battlefield‚Äù
  • Mod SDK UX (D020) ‚Äî ic mod install should be trivially simple

14. Asymmetric Faction Identity

Westwood believed that factions should never be mirrors of each other. GDI represents might and armor ‚Äî slow, expensive, powerful. Nod represents stealth and speed ‚Äî cheap, fragile, hit-and-run. The philosophy: balance doesn‚Äôt mean equal stats. It means every ‚Äúoverpowered‚Äù tool has a specific, skill-based counter.

This creates the experience that playing Faction B feels like a different game than playing Faction A ‚Äî different tempo, different priorities, different emotional arc. If you can swap faction skins and nothing changes, the faction design has failed.

Rule: When defining faction rules in YAML, design for identity contrast, not stat parity. Every faction strength should create a corresponding vulnerability. Balance is achieved through asymmetric counter-play, not symmetric stat lines. D019 (switchable balance presets) supports tuning the degree of asymmetry, but the principle holds across all presets.

Where this applies:

  • Unit and weapon definitions in YAML rules (04-MODDING.md)
  • Damage type matrices / versus tables (11-OPENRA-FEATURES.md)
  • Balance presets (D019) ‚Äî even the ‚Äúclassic‚Äù preset preserves Westwood‚Äôs asymmetric intent

15. The Core Loop ‚Äî Extract, Build, Amass, Crush

The most successful C&C titles follow a four-step core loop:

  1. Extract resources
  2. Build base
  3. Amass army
  4. Crush enemy

Every game system should feed into this loop. The original Westwood team learned (and EA relearned) that features which distract from the core loop ‚Äî hero units that overshadow armies, global powers that bypass base-building ‚Äî weaken the game‚Äôs identity. ‚ÄúKitchen sink‚Äù feature creep that doesn‚Äôt serve the loop produces unfocused games.

Rule: When evaluating a feature, ask: ‚ÄúWhich step of the core loop does this serve?‚Äù If the answer is ‚Äúnone ‚Äî it‚Äôs a parallel system,‚Äù the feature needs strong justification. This is the game-design-specific version of ‚ÄúScope to What You Have‚Äù (Principle 6).

Where this applies:

  • System design decisions in 02-ARCHITECTURE.md ‚Äî every sim system should map to a loop step
  • Feature proposals ‚Äî the first question after ‚Äúdoes it make the toy soldiers come alive?‚Äù is ‚Äúwhich loop step does it serve?‚Äù
  • Mod review guidelines ‚Äî total conversions can define their own loop, but the default RA1 module should stay faithful to this one

16. Game Feel ‚Äî ‚ÄúThe Juice‚Äù

Westwood (and later EA with the SAGE engine) understood that impact matters as much as mechanics. Buildings shouldn‚Äôt just vanish ‚Äî they should crumble. Debris should be physical. Explosions should feel weighty. Units should leave husks. During the Generals/C&C3 era, EA formalized this as ‚Äúphysics as fun‚Äù ‚Äî the visceral, physical feedback that makes commanding an army feel powerful.

The checklist: Do explosions feel impactful? Does the screen communicate force? Do destroyed units leave evidence that a battle happened? Do weapons feel different from each other ‚Äî not just in damage numbers, but in visual and audio weight?

Rule: ‚ÄúJuice‚Äù goes into the render and audio layers, not the sim. The sim tracks damage, death, and debris spawning deterministically. The renderer and audio system make it feel good. When a system works correctly but doesn‚Äôt feel satisfying, the problem is almost always missing juice, not missing mechanics.

Where this applies:

  • Rendering effects in ic-render ‚Äî destruction animations, particle effects, screen shake (all render-side, never sim-side)
  • Audio feedback in ic-audio ‚Äî weapon-specific impact sounds, explosion scaling
  • Modding: effects should be YAML-configurable (explosion type, debris count, screen shake intensity) so modders can tune game feel without code

17. Audio Drives Tempo

Frank Klepacki‚Äôs philosophy extended beyond ‚Äúwrite good music‚Äù to a specific insight about gameplay coupling: the music should match the tempo of the game. High-energy industrial metal and techno during combat keeps the player‚Äôs actions-per-minute high. Ambient tension during build-up phases lets the player think. ‚ÄúHell March‚Äù isn‚Äôt just a good track ‚Äî it‚Äôs a gameplay accelerator.

This extends to unit responses. Each unit‚Äôs voice should reflect its personality and role ‚Äî the bravado of a Commando, the professionalism of a Tank, the nervousness of a Conscript. Audio is characterization, not decoration.

Rule: Audio design (Phase 3) should be tested against gameplay tempo, not in isolation. Does the music make the player want to act? Do unit voices reinforce the fantasy? The ic-audio system should support dynamic music states (combat/exploration/tension) that respond to game state, not just random playlist shuffling.

Where this applies:

  • Dynamic music system in ic-audio (Phase 3)
  • Unit voice design guidelines for modders
  • Audio LOD ‚Äî critical feedback sounds (unit acknowledgment, attack alerts) must never be culled, even under heavy audio load

18. The Damage Matrix ‚Äî No Monocultures

The C&C series formalized damage types (armor-piercing, explosive, fire, etc.) against armor classes (none, light, heavy, wood, concrete) into explicit versus tables. This mathematical structure ensures that no single unit composition can dominate without a counter. Westwood established this with the original RA‚Äôs warhead/armor system; EA expanded it during the Generals/C&C3 era with more granular categories.

The design principle isn‚Äôt ‚Äúadd more damage types.‚Äù It‚Äôs: every viable strategy must have a viable counter-strategy. If playtesting reveals a monoculture (one unit type dominates), the versus table is the first place to look.

Rule: The damage pipeline (D028) should make the versus table moddable, inspectable, and central to balance work. The table is YAML data, not code. Balance presets (D019) may use different versus tables. The mod SDK should include tools to visualize the counter-play graph.

Where this applies:

  • Damage pipeline and versus tables in ic-sim (D028, Phase 2 hard requirement)
  • Balance preset definitions (D019)
  • Modding documentation ‚Äî versus table editing should be a first tutorial, not an advanced topic

19. Build for Surprise ‚Äî Powerful Enough to Transcend

The greatest validation of a modding system isn‚Äôt a balance tweak or an HD texture pack ‚Äî it‚Äôs when modders create something the engine developers never imagined. Warcraft III‚Äôs World Editor was designed for custom RTS maps. Modders built Defense of the Ancients (DotA), which spawned the entire MOBA genre ‚Äî a genre Blizzard didn‚Äôt envision and couldn‚Äôt have designed top-down. Doom‚Äôs WAD system was designed for custom levels. Modders built total conversions that influenced decades of first-person design. Half-Life‚Äôs SDK was designed for single-player mods. Counter-Strike became one of the most-played multiplayer games in history.

The pattern: expressive modding tools produce emergent creativity that transcends the original game‚Äôs genre. This doesn‚Äôt happen by accident. It requires the modding system to be powerful enough that the set of possible creations includes things the developers cannot enumerate in advance. A modding system that only supports ‚Äúvariations on what we shipped‚Äù cannot produce genre-defining surprises.

IC‚Äôs tiered modding architecture (D003/D004/D005) is explicitly designed with this in mind:

  • YAML (Tier 1) handles the 80% case ‚Äî balance mods, cosmetics, new units within existing mechanics. These are variations.
  • Lua (Tier 2) enables new game logic ‚Äî triggers, abilities, AI behaviors, mission mechanics that don‚Äôt exist in the base game.
  • WASM (Tier 3) enables new systems ‚Äî entirely new mechanics, game modes, even new genres running on the IC engine. A WASM module could implement a tower defense mode, a turn-based layer, a card game phase between battles, or something nobody has imagined.
  • Game modules (D018) go further ‚Äî a community-created game module can register its own system pipeline, pathfinder, spatial index, and renderer. At this level, IC is a platform, not a game.

Rule: When evaluating modding API design decisions, ask: ‚ÄúDoes this make it possible for modders to build something we can‚Äôt predict?‚Äù If an API only supports parameterizing existing behavior, it‚Äôs too narrow. If it exposes enough primitives that novel combinations are possible, it‚Äôs on the right track. The WC3 World Editor didn‚Äôt have a ‚Äúcreate MOBA‚Äù button ‚Äî it had flexible trigger scripting, custom UI, and unit ability composition. The emergent genre was an unplanned consequence of expressive tools.

Where this applies:

  • WASM host API design ‚Äî expose primitives, not just parameterized behaviors
  • Lua API extensions beyond OpenRA‚Äôs 16 globals ‚Äî IC‚Äôs superset should enable new game logic patterns
  • Game module trait design (D018) ‚Äî GameModule should be flexible enough for non-RTS game types
  • Workshop discovery (D030) ‚Äî total conversions and genre experiments deserve first-class visibility, not burial under ‚ÄúMaps‚Äù and ‚ÄúBalance Mods‚Äù

20. Narrative Identity ‚Äî Earnest Commitment, Never Ironic Distance

Scoping note: This principle synthesizes narrative aspects of Principle #14 (Asymmetric Faction Identity ‚Äî factions as worldviews) and Principle #17 (Audio Drives Tempo ‚Äî unit voice lines, EVA). Those principles focus on gameplay identity and audio design; this principle focuses on narrative voice and tone ‚Äî how characters speak, how stories are told, how content reads and sounds. They are complementary layers, not redundant.

Command & Conquer has one of the most distinctive narrative identities in gaming ‚Äî and it was discovered by accident. Westwood hired Joe Kucan, a Las Vegas community theater actor, to direct FMV cutscenes because nobody on the team had film experience. He turned out to be perfect as Kane ‚Äî a messianic cult leader who delivers monologues with absolute conviction, no winking, no self-consciousness. The other cast members were local talent and Westwood employees. The production values were modest. The performances were theatrical, intense, and utterly sincere. This accidental tone ‚Äî maximum dramatic commitment with minimal resources ‚Äî became the franchise‚Äôs soul.

The core principle: C&C plays everything straight at maximum volume. Stalin threatens you from a desk while a guard drags a man away. Kane declares ‚Äúpeace through power‚Äù while ordering genocide. Tim Curry escapes to ‚Äúthe one place that hasn‚Äôt been corrupted by capitalism ‚Äî SPACE!‚Äù Yuri mind-controls world leaders. Attack dolphins fight giant squid. A commando quips ‚ÄúThat was left-handed!‚Äù after demolishing an entire base. Einstein erases Hitler from the timeline and accidentally creates a worse war.

None of this is played ironically. Nobody winks at the camera. The actors commit fully ‚Äî and that sincerity is exactly what makes it memorable instead of cringe. C&C occupies a rare tonal space: simultaneously deadly serious and gloriously absurd, and the audience is in on it without being told they should laugh. The drama is real. The stakes are real. The world is ridiculous. All of these are true at the same time.

This is the opposite of ironic detachment, where creators signal ‚Äúwe know this is silly‚Äù to protect themselves from criticism. C&C never protects itself. Kane doesn‚Äôt say ‚ÄúI know I sound like a Bond villain.‚Äù Tanya doesn‚Äôt apologize for her one-liners. The EVA doesn‚Äôt make meta-commentary about being a video game. The world takes itself seriously ‚Äî and the audience loves it because it does.

The C&C narrative pillars:

  1. Larger-than-life characters. Every speaking role is a personality, not a role-filler. Commanders are charismatic or terrifying or both. Villains monologue. Heroes quip. Intelligence officers are suspiciously competent. Nobody delivers forgettable lines. If a character could be replaced with a generic text prompt, the character has failed.

  2. Cold War as mythology. The actual Cold War was bureaucratic brinksmanship. C&C‚Äôs Cold War is mythological: superweapons, psychic warfare, time travel, doomsday devices, continent-spanning battles, secret brotherhoods, and ideological conflict rendered as literal warfare between archetypes. Historical accuracy is raw material, not a constraint.

  3. Escalating absurdity with unwavering sincerity. Each game escalated: nuclear missiles ‚Üí chronosphere ‚Üí psychic dominators ‚Üí time travel. Each escalation was presented with complete seriousness. The escalation ladder should always go up ‚Äî every act raises the stakes ‚Äî and the presentation should never acknowledge the absurdity. The audience draws their own conclusions.

  4. Quotable lines over realistic dialogue. ‚ÄúKirov reporting.‚Äù ‚ÄúFor the Union!‚Äù ‚ÄúConscript reporting.‚Äù ‚ÄúRubber shoes in motion.‚Äù ‚ÄúInsufficient funds.‚Äù ‚ÄúConstruction complete.‚Äù ‚ÄúSilos needed.‚Äù ‚ÄúNuclear launch detected.‚Äù These lines aren‚Äôt naturalistic ‚Äî they‚Äôre iconic. They became memes, ringtones, inside jokes. Good C&C dialogue sacrifices realism for memorability every time.

  5. The briefing is the covenant. FMV briefings aren‚Äôt skippable filler ‚Äî they‚Äôre the emotional contract between the game and the player. A good briefing makes you want to play the mission. It establishes stakes, introduces personality, and gives you someone to fight for or against. Whether it‚Äôs a live-action commander staring into the camera, a radar comm portrait during gameplay, or a text-only tactical summary, the briefing sets the tone and the player carries that tone into battle.

  6. Factions as worldviews, not just armies. Allies aren‚Äôt just ‚Äúthe good guys with tanks‚Äù ‚Äî they represent Western liberal democratic values taken to their logical extreme (freedom through overwhelming technological superiority). Soviets aren‚Äôt just ‚Äúthe bad guys with numbers‚Äù ‚Äî they represent collectivist ideology rendered as raw industrial might. Nod isn‚Äôt just ‚Äúterrorists‚Äù ‚Äî they represent charismatic revolutionary ideology. These worldviews infuse everything: unit names, building aesthetics, voice lines, music, briefing style, even the UI theme.

  7. The camp is the canon. Trained attack dolphins. Psychic squids. Chronosphere mishaps. Generals named after their obvious personality trait. Superweapons with ominous names. None of this is an embarrassment to be refined away in a ‚Äúmore serious‚Äù sequel ‚Äî it is the franchise. Content that removes the camp removes the identity.

How this applies to IC:

This principle governs all IC-generated and IC-authored content ‚Äî not just hand-crafted campaigns, but LLM generation prompts (D016), EVA voice line design, unit voice guidance for modders, cheat code naming and flavor (D058), campaign briefing authoring (D021/D038), and the default ‚ÄúC&C Classic‚Äù story style for generative campaigns. It also sets the bar for community content: Workshop resources that claim ‚ÄúC&C Classic‚Äù style should be evaluated against these pillars.

Specific content generation rules:

  • EVA lines should be terse, authoritative, slightly ominous, and instantly recognizable. ‚ÄúOur base is under attack‚Äù is good. ‚ÄúWarning: hostile forces detected in proximity to primary installation‚Äù is bad.
  • Unit voice lines should express personality in 3 words or fewer. The unit is the line. A conscript sounds reluctant. A commando sounds cocky. A tank sounds professional. A Kirov sounds inevitable.
  • Mission briefings should make the player feel like something important is about to happen. Even routine missions get dramatic framing. ‚ÄúSecure the bridge‚Äù becomes ‚ÄúCommander, this bridge is the only thing between the enemy‚Äôs armor column and our civilian evacuation corridor. Lose it, and 50,000 people die.‚Äù
  • Villain dialogue should be quotable, not threatening. A villain who says ‚ÄúI will destroy you‚Äù is generic. A villain who says ‚ÄúI‚Äôve already won, Commander ‚Äî you just haven‚Äôt realized it yet‚Äù is C&C.
  • LLM system prompts (D016) for ‚ÄúC&C Classic‚Äù style must include these pillars explicitly. The LLM should be instructed to produce characters who would be at home in a RA1 FMV cutscene ‚Äî not characters from a Tom Clancy novel.
  • Cheat codes (D058) are named after Cold War phrases, C&C cultural moments, and franchise in-jokes ‚Äî because even the hidden mechanisms carry the world‚Äôs flavor.

The litmus test: Read a generated briefing, a unit voice line, or a mission description aloud. Does it sound like it belongs in a C&C game? Would a fan recognize it? Would someone quote it to a friend? If the answer is no, the content needs more personality and less professionalism.

Rule: When creating or reviewing narrative content for IC ‚Äî whether human-authored, LLM-generated, or community-submitted ‚Äî check it against the seven pillars above. C&C‚Äôs identity is its narrative voice. A technically perfect RTS with generic storytelling is not a C&C game. The camp, the conviction, and the quotability are as much a part of the engine‚Äôs identity as the ECS architecture or the fixed-point math.

Where this applies:

  • LLM system prompts and story style presets (09-DECISIONS.md ¬ß D016 ‚Äî ‚ÄúC&C Classic‚Äù is the default because of this principle)
  • Campaign authoring guidelines (09-DECISIONS.md ¬ß D021 ‚Äî briefings, character voices, narrative arc)
  • Cheat code and console command naming (09-DECISIONS.md ¬ß D058 ‚Äî Cold War/franchise cultural references)
  • EVA voice line design guidance for ic-audio (Phase 3)
  • Unit voice design guidelines for modders (04-MODDING.md)
  • Scenario editor content templates (09-DECISIONS.md ¬ß D038 ‚Äî briefing authoring, character creation)
  • Workshop content review criteria (09-DECISIONS.md ¬ß D030 ‚Äî ‚ÄúC&C Classic‚Äù style validation)
  • The foreword, README, and all public-facing project communication ‚Äî IC‚Äôs own voice should reflect the franchise it serves (direct, confident, unpretentious)

Engineering Methods

These are not principles ‚Äî they‚Äôre specific engineering practices validated by Westwood‚Äôs code and OpenRA‚Äôs 18 years of open-source development.

Integer Math in the Simulation

Westwood used integer arithmetic exclusively for game logic. Not because floats were slow in 1995 ‚Äî because deterministic multiplayer requires bitwise-identical results across all clients. The EA GPL source confirms this. The Remastered Collection preserved it. OpenRA continued it.

This is settled engineering. D009 / Invariant #1. Don‚Äôt revisit it.

The OutList / DoList Order Pattern

The original engine separates ‚Äúwhat the player wants‚Äù (OutList) from ‚Äúwhat the simulation executes‚Äù (DoList). Network code touches both. Simulation code only reads DoList. IC‚Äôs PlayerOrder ‚Üí TickOrders ‚Üí apply_tick() pipeline is the same pattern. The crate boundary (ic-sim never imports ic-net) enforces at the compiler level what Westwood achieved through discipline. See 03-NETCODE.md.

Composition Over Inheritance

OpenRA‚Äôs trait system assembles units from composable behaviors in YAML. IC‚Äôs Bevy ECS does the same with components. Both are direct descendants of Westwood‚Äôs INI-driven data approach. The architecture is compatible at the conceptual level (D023 maps trait names to component names), even though the implementations are completely different. See 04-MODDING.md and 11-OPENRA-FEATURES.md.

Design for Extraction

The Remastered team extracted Westwood‚Äôs 1995 sim as a callable DLL. Design every IC system so it could be extracted, replaced, or wrapped. This is why ic-sim is a library, not an application ‚Äî and why ic-protocol exists as the shared boundary between sim and network.

Layered Pathfinding Heuristics

Louis Castle described specific heuristics for avoiding ‚ÄúArtificial Idiocy‚Äù in high-unit-count movement:

  1. Ignore Moving Friendlies: Assume they will be gone by the time you get there.
  2. Wiggle Static Friendlies: If blocked, try to push the blocker aside slightly.
  3. Repath: Only calculate a new long-distance path if the first two fail.

This validates IC‚Äôs tiered pathfinding approach (D013). Perfection is expensive; ‚Äúnot looking stupid‚Äù is the goal.

Write Comments That Explain Why

Bostic read his 25-year-old comments and remembered the thought process. Write for your future self ‚Äî and for the LLM agent that will read your code in 2028. Comments should explain why, not what. The code shows what; the comment shows intent.

Warnings ‚Äî What Went Wrong

These are cautionary tales from the same people whose principles we follow. They‚Äôre as important as the successes.

The ‚ÄúEvery Game Must Be a Hit‚Äù Trap

Bostic on Westwood‚Äôs decline: ‚ÄúWestwood had eventually succumbed to the corporate ‚Äòevery game must be a big hit‚Äô mentality and that affected the size of the projects as well as the internal culture. This shift from passion to profit took its toll.‚Äù

IC Lesson: IC is a passion project. If it ever starts feeling like obligation, revisit this warning. The 36-month roadmap is ambitious but structured so each phase produces a usable artifact ‚Äî not just ‚Äúprogress toward a distant goal.‚Äù Scope to what a small passionate team can build.

The Recompilation Barrier

OpenRA‚Äôs C# trait system is more modder-hostile than Westwood‚Äôs original INI files. Total conversions require C# programming. This is a step backward from the 1995 approach.

IC Lesson: D003/D004/D005 (YAML ‚Üí Lua ‚Üí WASM) explicitly address this. 80% of mods should need zero compilation. The modding bar should be lower than the original game‚Äôs, not higher. See 04-MODDING.md.

Knowledge Concentration Kills Projects

OpenRA, despite 339 contributors and 16.4k GitHub stars, has critical features blocked because they depend on 1‚Äì2 individuals. Tiberian Sun support has been ‚Äúnext‚Äù for years. Release frequency has declined.

IC Lesson: Design so knowledge isn‚Äôt concentrated. IC‚Äôs design docs, AGENTS.md, and decision rationale (09-DECISIONS.md) exist so any contributor can understand why a system exists, not just what it does. When key people leave ‚Äî as they always eventually do ‚Äî the documentation and architectural clarity are what survive.

Design Debt Becomes Identity

OpenRA‚Äôs early balance compromises (made before core features existed) became permanent gameplay identity. When the team tried to reconsider, the community split into ‚ÄúOriginal Red Alert‚Äù vs. ‚ÄúOriginal OpenRA‚Äù factions.

IC Lesson: This is why D019 (switchable balance presets) and D033 (toggleable QoL) exist. Don‚Äôt make one-off compromises that become permanent. If you must compromise, make it a toggle.

OpenRA ‚Äî What They Got Right, What They Struggled With

IC studies OpenRA not to copy it, but to learn from 18 years of open-source RTS development. We take their best ideas and avoid their pain points.

Successes to Learn From

WhatWhy It Matters to ICIC Equivalent
Trait system moddabilityYAML-configurable behavior without recompilation (for most changes)Bevy ECS + YAML rules (D003, D023)
Cross-platform from day oneWindows, macOS, Linux, *BSD ‚Äî proved the community exists on all platformsInvariant #10 + WASM/mobile targets
18 years of sustained devVolunteer project survival ‚Äî proves the model worksPhased roadmap, public design docs
Community-driven balanceRAGL (15+ competitive seasons) directly influencing designD019 switchable presets, future ranked play
Third-party mod ecosystemCombined Arms, Romanov‚Äôs Vengeance, OpenHV prove the modding architecture worksD020 Mod SDK, D030 workshop registry
EA relationshipFrom cautious distance to active collaboration, GPL source releaseD011 community layer, respectful coexistence

Pain Points to Avoid

WhatWhy It HurtsHow IC Avoids It
C# barrier for moddersTotal conversions require C# ‚Äî higher bar than original INI filesYAML ‚Üí Lua ‚Üí WASM tiers (D003/D004/D005)
TCP lockstep networkingHigher latency; 135+ desync issues in tracker; sync buffer only 7 frames deepUDP relay lockstep, deeper desync diagnosis (D007)
MiniYAMLCustom format, no standard tooling, no IDE supportReal YAML with serde_yaml (D003)
Single-threaded simPerformance ceiling for large battlesBevy ECS scheduling, efficiency pyramid first
Early design debtBalance compromises became permanent identity, split the communitySwitchable presets (D019), toggles (D033)
Manpower concentrationCritical features blocked because 1‚Äì2 people hold the knowledgePublic design docs, documented decision rationale

How to Use This Chapter

For Code Review

When reviewing a PR or design proposal, check it against these principles ‚Äî but don‚Äôt use them as a rigid gate. The original creators discovered their best ideas by breaking their own rules. The principles provide grounding when a decision feels uncertain. They should never prevent innovation.

Key questions to ask during review: 0. Is this the game the community actually wants? The community wants to play Red Alert ‚Äî the real thing, not a diminished version ‚Äî forever, on anything, with anyone, and to make it their own. Does this feature, system, or decision bring that game closer to existing? If it‚Äôs architecture that doesn‚Äôt serve a playable game, it needs strong justification.

  1. Does this serve the core fantasy, or is it infrastructure for infrastructure‚Äôs sake?
  2. Does this keep the sim pure, or does it leak I/O into game logic?
  3. Could a modder change this value without recompiling? Should they be able to?
  4. Is this scoped appropriately for the current phase?
  5. If this is a compromise, is it explicitly labeled and reversible?
  6. How does this affect the community ‚Äî players, modders, server hosts, contributors? Does it address a known pain point or create a new one?
  7. If this touches the modding API, does it expose primitives that enable novel creations, or only parameterize existing behavior?
  8. If this involves narrative content (briefings, dialogue, EVA lines, cheat names, LLM prompts), does it follow the seven C&C narrative pillars? Would a fan recognize it as C&C?

For Feature Proposals

When proposing a new feature:

  1. Does this bring the game closer to existing? The most important feature is a playable game. If this proposal doesn‚Äôt serve that, it must justify why it‚Äôs worth the time.
  2. State which principle(s) it serves
  3. Cross-reference the relevant design docs (02-ARCHITECTURE.md, 08-ROADMAP.md, etc.)
  4. If it conflicts with a principle, acknowledge the trade-off ‚Äî don‚Äôt pretend the conflict doesn‚Äôt exist
  5. Check 09-DECISIONS.md ‚Äî has this already been decided?
  6. Consider community impact ‚Äî does this address a known pain point? Does it create friction for existing workflows? Check 01-VISION.md and 11-OPENRA-FEATURES.md for documented community needs

For LLM Agents

If you‚Äôre an AI agent working on this project:

  • Read AGENTS.md first (it points here)
  • These principles inform design review, not design generation ‚Äî don‚Äôt refuse to implement something just because it doesn‚Äôt fit a principle. Implement it, then flag the tension
  • When two approaches seem equally valid, the principle that applies most directly is the tiebreaker
  • When no principle applies, use engineering judgment and document the rationale in 09-DECISIONS.md

Sources & Further Reading

All principles in this chapter are sourced from public interviews, documentation, and GPL-released source code. Full quotes, attribution, and links are in the research file:

‚Üí research/westwood-ea-development-philosophy.md ‚Äî Complete collection of quotes, interviews, source analysis, and detailed IC application notes for every principle in this chapter.

Key People Referenced

Westwood Studios / EA: Joe Bostic (lead programmer & designer), Brett Sperry (co-founder), Louis Castle (co-founder), Frank Klepacki (composer & audio director), Mike Legg (programmer & designer), Denzil Long (software engineer), Jim Vessella (EA producer, C&C Remastered).

OpenRA: Paul Chote (lead maintainer 2013‚Äì2021), Chris Forbes (early core developer, architecture docs), PunkPun / Gustas Ka≈æukauskas (current active maintainer).

Interview Sources

  • Joe Bostic ‚Äî Westwood Studios (2018)
  • Joe Bostic ‚Äî C&C Remastered (2020)
  • Frank Klepacki ‚Äî Westwood Studios (2017)
  • Mike Legg ‚Äî EA/Westwood Studios (2019)
  • Denzil Long ‚Äî Command and Conquer (2018)
  • Louis Castle ‚Äî Ars Technica: ‚ÄúWar Stories‚Äù (2019)
  • Paul Chote ‚Äî OpenRA Balance Philosophy (2018)
  • Paul Chote ‚Äî OpenRA vs Remastered (2020)

14 ‚Äî Development Methodology

How Iron Curtain moves from design docs to a playable game ‚Äî the meta-process that governs everything from research through release.

Purpose of This Chapter

The other design docs say what we‚Äôre building (01-VISION, 02-ARCHITECTURE), why decisions were made (09-DECISIONS, 13-PHILOSOPHY), and when things ship (08-ROADMAP). This chapter says how we get there ‚Äî the methodology that turns 13 design documents into a working engine.

When to read this chapter:

  • You‚Äôre starting work on a new phase and need to know the process
  • You‚Äôre an agent (human or AI) about to write code and need to understand the workflow
  • You‚Äôre planning which tasks to tackle next within a phase
  • You need to understand how isolated development, integration, and community feedback fit together

When NOT to read this chapter:

  • You need architecture specifics ‚Üí 02-ARCHITECTURE.md
  • You need performance guidance ‚Üí 10-PERFORMANCE.md
  • You need the phase timeline ‚Üí 08-ROADMAP.md
  • You need coding rules for agents ‚Üí see Stage 6 below, plus AGENTS.md ¬ß ‚ÄúWorking With This Codebase‚Äù

The Eight Stages

Development follows eight stages. They‚Äôre roughly sequential, but later stages feed back into earlier ones ‚Äî implementation teaches us things that update the design.

‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
‚îÇ 1. Research          ‚îÇ ‚óÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
‚îÇ    & Document        ‚îÇ                                          ‚îÇ
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î¨‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò                                          ‚îÇ
           ‚ñº                                                      ‚îÇ
‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê                                          ‚îÇ
‚îÇ 2. Architectural     ‚îÇ                                          ‚îÇ
‚îÇ    Blueprint         ‚îÇ                                          ‚îÇ
